name: WordPress
notes:
**Deep-link support:** Built-in (Silktide handles the Edit button).
**What to do:** Follow the Silktide integration guide in `silktide_help_url`.
**Editor experience:** Users click **Edit** in Silktide and are taken to the correct item in the CMS.
notes_original: Silktide provides a built-in integration for deep-linking (Edit button).

name: Cascade CMS (Hannon Hill)
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Site template/header include used across all pages.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Cascade authoring is asset-ID driven; store/emit the relevant asset ID for the published page.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{CASCADE_HOST}/entity/open.act?id={ASSET_ID}&type=page (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Cascade editor URLs are asset-ID based; public URLs typically do not include the internal asset ID, so Silktide cannot reliably derive editor links via URL transform. Output a per-page silktide-cms meta tag containing the correct editorUrl.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Cascade authoring is asset-ID driven; store/emit the relevant asset ID for the published page.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Site template/header include used across all pages.

name: TYPO3
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Global frontend <head> (Fluid layout / sitepackage) so every page emits its own editorUrl.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Use the current page UID from TYPO3 during render (page tree node UID).
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{SITE}/typo3/record/edit?edit[pages][{PAGE_UID}]=edit (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: TYPO3 backend deep links include internal page uid and often a security token/route; public URL alone isn’t enough. Use meta tag built from page uid + backend route.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Use the current page UID from TYPO3 during render (page tree node UID).
editor_context.where_to_inject: Global frontend <head> (Fluid layout / sitepackage) so every page emits its own editorUrl.

name: Joomla
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Template <head> override (or system plugin) to emit the meta tag per page.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** If the page is an article, use the article ID; for menu items/components, map to the underlying entity ID.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{SITE}/administrator/index.php?option=com_content&task=article.edit&id={ARTICLE_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Use a per-page silktide-cms meta tag to provide the exact editor URL for each page.

editor_context.id_source_hint: If the page is an article, use the article ID; for menu items/components, map to the underlying entity ID.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Template <head> override (or system plugin) to emit the meta tag per page.

name: Shopify
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** theme.liquid <head> (or equivalent layout) with logic per template type.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** In Liquid, many templates expose object IDs (e.g., product.id, page.id, article.id). Use the relevant one.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://admin.shopify.com/store/{STORE_HANDLE}/pages/{PAGE_ID}; https://admin.shopify.com/store/{STORE_HANDLE}/products/{PRODUCT_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Admin URLs are ID-based; in Liquid you can access object.id for products/pages/blog posts and build the editorUrl meta tag.

editor_context.id_source_hint: In Liquid, many templates expose object IDs (e.g., product.id, page.id, article.id). Use the relevant one.
editor_context.where_to_inject: theme.liquid <head> (or equivalent layout) with logic per template type.

name: Adobe Commerce (Magento)
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Frontend theme head block; compute editorUrl server-side.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Use entity IDs from Magento models (product ID, CMS page ID). Avoid including form keys/tokens.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{SITE}/admin/*/catalog/product/edit/id/{PRODUCT_ID}; https://{SITE}/admin/*/cms/page/edit/page_id/{PAGE_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Admin edit screens use entity IDs and often require an authenticated session; do not include tokens in editor URLs. Use meta tag with non-tokenized edit URL.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Use entity IDs from Magento models (product ID, CMS page ID). Avoid including form keys/tokens.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Frontend theme head block; compute editorUrl server-side.

name: BigCommerce
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Storefront theme <head> (Stencil) with context-aware variables.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Use the internal object ID if available in templates; if not, you'll need a mapping from URL/slug to ID.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://store-{STORE_HASH}.mybigcommerce.com/manage/products/{PRODUCT_ID}; https://store-{STORE_HASH}.mybigcommerce.com/manage/pages/{PAGE_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Admin edit screens are ID-based. Use storefront templates to emit meta tag if you can access product/page IDs; otherwise rely on URL transform is not recommended.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Use the internal object ID if available in templates; if not, you'll need a mapping from URL/slug to ID.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Storefront theme <head> (Stencil) with context-aware variables.

name: Webflow
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Not feasible (no stable page-specific editor URL).
**Recommendation:** Link to the CMS dashboard or relevant content list, or omit Edit links for this CMS.
**Context:** Webflow editing URLs are not reliably derivable from public URLs without internal IDs; deep linking to a specific page is typically not feasible.
notes_original: Webflow editing URLs are not reliably derivable from public URLs without internal IDs; deep linking to a specific page is typically not feasible.

name: Wix
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Not feasible (no stable page-specific editor URL).
**Recommendation:** Link to the CMS dashboard or relevant content list, or omit Edit links for this CMS.
**Context:** Deep linking to edit a specific page is generally not feasible; Wix uses editor/session context. Consider linking to the site dashboard only, or skip edit links.
notes_original: Deep linking to edit a specific page is generally not feasible; Wix uses editor/session context. Consider linking to the site dashboard only, or skip edit links.

name: Squarespace
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Not feasible (no stable page-specific editor URL).
**Recommendation:** Link to the CMS dashboard or relevant content list, or omit Edit links for this CMS.
**Context:** Page-specific edit deep links are generally not feasible; editor URLs are not stable per page. Consider linking to the site dashboard only, or skip edit links.
notes_original: Page-specific edit deep links are generally not feasible; editor URLs are not stable per page. Consider linking to the site dashboard only, or skip edit links.

name: HubSpot CMS
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** HubSpot theme templates (<head>) or module that renders on all pages.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Needs portalId + contentId; if templates can access them, emit directly; otherwise you may need a lookup/mapping layer.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://app.hubspot.com/content/{PORTAL_ID}/edit/{CONTENT_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: HubSpot editor URLs include portal ID and content ID. If your templates can access these IDs, emit meta tag; otherwise edit deep links may be limited.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Needs portalId + contentId; if templates can access them, emit directly; otherwise you may need a lookup/mapping layer.
editor_context.where_to_inject: HubSpot theme templates (<head>) or module that renders on all pages.

name: Sitecore
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** URL transform (Silktide derives the editor URL by manipulating the public URL).
**Transform rule:** Commonly add `sc_mode=edit` (and sometimes `sc_lang`/`sc_site`) or use an Experience Editor host mapping.
**Notes:** Varies by Sitecore version and routing; if the editor requires item IDs, use meta tag instead.
**When to use meta tag instead:** If the CMS editor URL requires internal IDs (e.g., pageId/itemId) that are not present in the public URL.
notes_original: Many Sitecore sites support Experience Editor via predictable URL changes (e.g., query params like sc_mode=edit and/or host swap). If your setup requires item IDs, use the meta tag strategy.

editor_context.transform_rule: Commonly add `sc_mode=edit` (and sometimes `sc_lang`/`sc_site`) or use an Experience Editor host mapping.
editor_context.limitations: Varies by Sitecore version and routing; if the editor requires item IDs, use meta tag instead.

name: Optimizely CMS
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Depends (URL transform may work in some setups; meta tag is the safe default).
**Decision rule:** If you can deterministically map the public URL to an editor URL without internal IDs, use URL transform. Otherwise use the meta tag.
**Context:** Optimizely supports on-page editing; some implementations use epieditmode=True on specific CMS URLs (often includes internal IDs). Treat as meta tag by default, but URL transform may work if your preview URLs are deterministic.
notes_original: Optimizely supports on-page editing; some implementations use epieditmode=True on specific CMS URLs (often includes internal IDs). Treat as meta tag by default, but URL transform may work if your preview URLs are deterministic.

name: Kentico Xperience
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Depends (URL transform may work in some setups; meta tag is the safe default).
**Decision rule:** If you can deterministically map the public URL to an editor URL without internal IDs, use URL transform. Otherwise use the meta tag.
**Context:** Often requires internal identifiers (NodeID/DocumentID). If on-site editing is enabled, some setups allow an edit-mode URL derived from the public path (e.g., /cmsctx/... + editmode=1). Otherwise use meta tag built from CMS IDs.
notes_original: Often requires internal identifiers (NodeID/DocumentID). If on-site editing is enabled, some setups allow an edit-mode URL derived from the public path (e.g., /cmsctx/... + editmode=1). Otherwise use meta tag built from CMS IDs.

name: SharePoint Online
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** URL transform (Silktide derives the editor URL by manipulating the public URL).
**Transform rule:** Tenant/page-type dependent. Where supported, use an edit-mode parameter (e.g., `?Mode=Edit`) or link to the Pages library edit UI.
**Notes:** SharePoint URL shapes vary; if edit-mode URLs aren't stable, link to the Pages library or use meta tag if you can inject it.
**When to use meta tag instead:** If the CMS editor URL requires internal IDs (e.g., pageId/itemId) that are not present in the public URL.
notes_original: Some SharePoint Online pages can be opened in edit mode via predictable URL parameters (varies by tenant/page type). If not, fall back to meta tag with internal IDs or link to the site’s Pages/Library UI.

editor_context.transform_rule: Tenant/page-type dependent. Where supported, use an edit-mode parameter (e.g., `?Mode=Edit`) or link to the Pages library edit UI.
editor_context.limitations: SharePoint URL shapes vary; if edit-mode URLs aren't stable, link to the Pages library or use meta tag if you can inject it.

name: Liferay DXP
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** URL transform (Silktide derives the editor URL by manipulating the public URL).
**Transform rule:** Add `p_l_mode=edit` to the page URL query string (e.g., `...?p_l_mode=edit`).
**Notes:** Requires permissions; portals may still accept this even with friendly URLs.
**When to use meta tag instead:** If the CMS editor URL requires internal IDs (e.g., pageId/itemId) that are not present in the public URL.
notes_original: Liferay pages can be opened in edit mode by adding p_l_mode=edit to the page URL (requires permissions).

editor_context.transform_rule: Add `p_l_mode=edit` to the page URL query string (e.g., `...?p_l_mode=edit`).
editor_context.limitations: Requires permissions; portals may still accept this even with friendly URLs.

name: Magnolia
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** In the global frontend `<head>` so every page emits a `silktide-cms` meta tag.
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Typically edited via AdminCentral/Pages app and internal node paths/UUIDs; no universal 1:1 URL transform from public URL. Use meta tag built from Magnolia page node info.

name: Contentful
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Your frontend app layout/head; can be server-rendered or injected at build time.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Emit the Contentful entry ID used to render the page (plus space/environment).
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://app.contentful.com/spaces/{SPACE_ID}/environments/{ENV_ID}/entries/{ENTRY_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Headless: frontend can emit meta tag with the entry ID and a preconfigured space/environment.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Emit the Contentful entry ID used to render the page (plus space/environment).
editor_context.where_to_inject: Your frontend app layout/head; can be server-rendered or injected at build time.

name: Sanity
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Frontend head; many setups already have document data at render time.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Emit the Sanity document _id (and optionally _type) used for the page; studio host is customer-specific.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{STUDIO_HOST}/intent/edit/id={DOC_ID};type={DOC_TYPE} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Headless: emit meta tag with document ID and studio URL (often uses intents).

editor_context.id_source_hint: Emit the Sanity document _id (and optionally _type) used for the page; studio host is customer-specific.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Frontend head; many setups already have document data at render time.

name: Prismic
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Frontend head in the app that renders Prismic content.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Emit the Prismic document ID (or UID) used for the page; repo name is customer-specific.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{REPO}.prismic.io/documents~b=working&documentId={DOC_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Headless: emit meta tag with document ID/UID and repository name.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Emit the Prismic document ID (or UID) used for the page; repo name is customer-specific.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Frontend head in the app that renders Prismic content.

name: Storyblok
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Frontend head; Storyblok SDK already passes story info in preview modes.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Emit Story ID and Space ID; Storyblok content APIs usually provide story.id.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://app.storyblok.com/#/me/spaces/{SPACE_ID}/stories/0/0/{STORY_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Headless: emit meta tag with story ID and space ID, pointing into the Visual Editor.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Emit Story ID and Space ID; Storyblok content APIs usually provide story.id.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Frontend head; Storyblok SDK already passes story info in preview modes.

name: Strapi
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Frontend head (SSR/templating) once you know which entry rendered the page.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Emit the collection type and entry ID used for rendering; admin host may differ from public host.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{ADMIN_HOST}/admin/content-manager/collectionType/api::{API_NAME}.{TYPE}/{ENTRY_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Emit meta tag with collection type + entry ID and Strapi admin URL.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Emit the collection type and entry ID used for rendering; admin host may differ from public host.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Frontend head (SSR/templating) once you know which entry rendered the page.

name: Contentstack
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Frontend head in your site/app.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Emit stack UID + content type UID + entry UID used for the page.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://app.contentstack.com/#!/stack/{STACK_UID}/content-types/{CT_UID}/entries/{ENTRY_UID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Use a per-page silktide-cms meta tag to provide the exact editor URL for each page.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Emit stack UID + content type UID + entry UID used for the page.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Frontend head in your site/app.

name: Ghost
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** URL transform (Silktide derives the editor URL by manipulating the public URL).
**Transform rule:** Append `/edit` to the public URL path (e.g., `https://site.com/post` → `https://site.com/post/edit`).
**Notes:** Requires the user to be logged in; Ghost may redirect to login first.
**When to use meta tag instead:** If the CMS editor URL requires internal IDs (e.g., pageId/itemId) that are not present in the public URL.
notes_original: Ghost supports a front-end “/edit” shortcut: append /edit to the public post/page URL to redirect to the editor (login required).

editor_context.transform_rule: Append `/edit` to the public URL path (e.g., `https://site.com/post` → `https://site.com/post/edit`).
editor_context.limitations: Requires the user to be logged in; Ghost may redirect to login first.

name: WooCommerce
notes:
**Deep-link support:** Built-in (Silktide handles the Edit button).
**What to do:** Follow the Silktide integration guide in `silktide_help_url`.
**Editor experience:** Users click **Edit** in Silktide and are taken to the correct item in the CMS.
notes_original: Silktide provides a built-in integration for deep-linking (Edit button).

name: PrestaShop
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Theme header template with per-page variables.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Use internal IDs (product ID, CMS page ID). Avoid any security tokens in the URL.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{SITE}/admin*/index.php?controller=AdminProducts&id_product={PRODUCT_ID}&updateproduct=1; https://{SITE}/admin*/index.php?controller=AdminCmsContent&id_cms={CMS_PAGE_ID}&updatecms=1 (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Admin edit URLs typically require internal IDs (product/category/CMS page).

editor_context.id_source_hint: Use internal IDs (product ID, CMS page ID). Avoid any security tokens in the URL.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Theme header template with per-page variables.

name: Shopware
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Storefront head; requires access to entity IDs in template context.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Use Shopware entity IDs (often UUIDs) for products/categories/pages.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{ADMIN_HOST}/admin#/sw/product/detail/{PRODUCT_ID}; https://{ADMIN_HOST}/admin#/sw/category/detail/{CATEGORY_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Admin edit URLs usually include entity IDs; public slugs aren’t enough.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Use Shopware entity IDs (often UUIDs) for products/categories/pages.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Storefront head; requires access to entity IDs in template context.

name: Plone
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** URL transform (Silktide derives the editor URL by manipulating the public URL).
**Transform rule:** Append `/edit` to the public URL (e.g., `https://site.com/page` → `https://site.com/page/edit`).
**Notes:** Requires editor permissions; some sites may customize actions/paths.
**When to use meta tag instead:** If the CMS editor URL requires internal IDs (e.g., pageId/itemId) that are not present in the public URL.
notes_original: Plone supports action URLs like /edit on the same content URL, so editorUrl can be derived from the public URL.

editor_context.limitations: Requires editor permissions; some sites may customize actions/paths.

name: django CMS
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** URL transform (Silktide derives the editor URL by manipulating the public URL).
**Transform rule:** If the toolbar edit mode is enabled, use an edit-mode flag such as `?edit` (implementation-specific).
**Notes:** Depends on django CMS toolbar configuration; if uncertain, treat as 'depends' and fall back to meta tag.
**When to use meta tag instead:** If the CMS editor URL requires internal IDs (e.g., pageId/itemId) that are not present in the public URL.
notes_original: Many setups allow entering edit mode by appending ?edit to the current page URL (logged-in editors).

editor_context.transform_rule: If the toolbar edit mode is enabled, use an edit-mode flag such as `?edit` (implementation-specific).
editor_context.limitations: Depends on django CMS toolbar configuration; if uncertain, treat as 'depends' and fall back to meta tag.

name: MODX
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Template head via placeholders/snippets.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** MODX resources have numeric IDs; emit the current resource ID.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{SITE}/manager/?a=resource/update&id={RESOURCE_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Manager edit URLs are resource-ID based; public slugs don’t reliably include IDs.

editor_context.id_source_hint: MODX resources have numeric IDs; emit the current resource ID.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Template head via placeholders/snippets.

name: Silverstripe CMS
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Theme layout head (or controller) where page ID is available.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Emit the page record ID used by Silverstripe.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{SITE}/admin/pages/edit/show/{PAGE_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Admin edit routes are ID-based (pages/records).

editor_context.id_source_hint: Emit the page record ID used by Silverstripe.
editor_context.where_to_inject: Theme layout head (or controller) where page ID is available.

name: Concrete CMS (Concrete5)
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Depends (URL transform may work in some setups; meta tag is the safe default).
**Decision rule:** If you can deterministically map the public URL to an editor URL without internal IDs, use URL transform. Otherwise use the meta tag.
**Context:** Some sites use on-page editing (same URL for editors), others route through dashboard pages with cID. If you can reliably derive edit mode from public URL, use transform; otherwise meta tag with page ID.
notes_original: Some sites use on-page editing (same URL for editors), others route through dashboard pages with cID. If you can reliably derive edit mode from public URL, use transform; otherwise meta tag with page ID.

name: ProcessWire
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Main layout/head template.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Emit the ProcessWire page id ($page->id).
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{SITE}/admin/page/edit/?id={PAGE_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Admin edit URLs require the page ID; public URL is path-based.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Emit the ProcessWire page id ($page->id).
editor_context.where_to_inject: Main layout/head template.

name: October CMS
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** In the global frontend `<head>` so every page emits a `silktide-cms` meta tag.
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Back-end editing is record-ID based and front-end URLs are developer-defined.

name: Statamic
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Depends (URL transform may work in some setups; meta tag is the safe default).
**Decision rule:** If you can deterministically map the public URL to an editor URL without internal IDs, use URL transform. Otherwise use the meta tag.
**Context:** Entry editing URLs in the Control Panel depend on collection/blueprint structure. If your public paths map cleanly to CP entry routes, use transform; otherwise generate editorUrl in meta tag from entry identifiers.
notes_original: Entry editing URLs in the Control Panel depend on collection/blueprint structure. If your public paths map cleanly to CP entry routes, use transform; otherwise generate editorUrl in meta tag from entry identifiers.

name: Directus
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** Frontend head.
**How to build `editorUrl`:** Emit collection name + item ID used for the page.
**Common editor URL pattern(s):** https://{ADMIN_HOST}/admin/content/{COLLECTION}/{ITEM_ID} (varies by instance).
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Editor UI is collection + item-ID based; public URLs are app-specific.

editor_context.id_source_hint: Emit collection name + item ID used for the page.

notes_original: Authoring UI uses internal asset IDs; public URL mapping varies.

name: Tridion Sites (SDL Tridion)
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Meta tag (each page outputs its own editor URL).
**Why:** The CMS editor URL typically needs internal IDs/UUIDs that cannot be derived from the public URL alone.
**Where to implement:** In the global frontend `<head>` so every page emits a `silktide-cms` meta tag.
**Security:** Do not include tokens/session keys in the editorUrl (Base64 is reversible).
notes_original: Editing is ID-based (items/components/pages) and not derivable from public URLs.

name: HCL Digital Experience (DX)
notes:
**Deep-link approach:** Depends (URL transform may work in some setups; meta tag is the safe default).
**Decision rule:** If you can deterministically map the public URL to an editor URL without internal IDs, use URL transform. Otherwise use the meta tag.
**Context:** Some deployments support in-context editing on the live URL; others require control panel routes with internal IDs. If edit mode can be enabled via URL parameters, use transform; otherwise generate editorUrl via meta tag using internal IDs.
notes_original: Some deployments support in-context editing on the live URL; others require control panel routes with internal IDs. If edit mode can be enabled via URL parameters, use transform; otherwise generate editorUrl via meta tag using internal IDs.
